questions.text: An Intern gave Lignocaine plus adrenaline for suturing a cut wound on the forearm. He sutured it quickly and wanted to shorten the duration of soft-tissue anesthesia. Which of the following is FDA approved drug to reverse or shorten the duration of soft-tissue anesthesia when Sympathomimetics is used with local anesthetics?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Phentolamine Phentolamine is a reversible nonselective α-adrenergic antagonist. Its primary action is vasodilation due to α1 blockade. Non-selective α-blockers can cause a much more pronounced reflex tachycardia than selective α1 blockers.

Highyeild:

FDA approved to reverse or shorten the duration of soft-tissue anesthesia Sympathomimetics(adrenaline) are frequently administered with local anesthetics to prolong the action of local anesthetics Sympathomimetics(adrenaline) slow the removal of the anesthetic by causing vasoconstriction When the need for anesthesia is over, phentolamine can help reverse it by antagonizing the α-receptor-induced vasoconstriction Phentolamine’s ability to block 𝛂-adrenergic receptors on blood vessels induces vasodilation and enhances the redistribution of the local anesthetic away from the injection site.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B: Phenoxybenzamine is an irreversible antagonist whereas phentolamine and tolazolin are reversible blockers of alpha 1 and alpha 2 receptors. These agents result in vasodilation and postural hypotension Options C & D: Prazosin and Bunazosin are selective alpha 1 blockers and are not given here.

Extraedge:

Potent competitive antagonist at both 1 and 2 receptors Quick acting (in minutes) Reduction in Peripheral Resistance - blocking both α-1 and α-2 receptors - causes NA release and venodilatation more than arteriolar Cardiac stimulation: Enhanced NA release due to alpha-2 blockade Inhibits serotonin release - muscarinic agonist (?) Uses: Pheochromocytoma, clonidine withdrawal, cheese reaction and in extravasations of NA and Adr injection

questions.text: A 62-year-old male had BPH and his BP is 150/90mm of Hg. Which is the Best drug for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Alfuzosin Alfuzosin is a selective α1 antagonist used for hypertension with BPH because it blocks alpha 1 on blood vessels and prostatic urethra . So a sing le drug can manage both BPH and hypertension

Highyeild:

𝛂1 blockers are of 2 types: 𝛂1A 𝛂1B Acts on prostatic urethra Acts on blood vessels Tamsulosin Silodosin - No postural hypotension - DOC for normotensives with BHP

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A. Phenoxybenzamine is a non-selective, irreversible alpha blocker. It is used in the treatment of hypertension, and specifically that caused by pheochromocytoma. Option B. Tamsulosin is used in the treatment of benign prostatic hyperplasia. It helps to empty the bladder completely and reduces the need to pass urine frequently or urgently. However, it does not decrease the size of the prostate. Option D. Phentolamine is a medication that is used to treat high blood pressure due to pheochromocytoma, skin problems from some drugs, and to reverse the effects of some drugs1. It is also marketed in the dental field as a local anesthetic reversal agent2. Phentolamine is a reversible nonselective α- adrenergic antagonist2. Its primary action is vasodilation due to α 1 blockade

questions.text: A 22-year-old female had a scorpion bite and developed pulmonary odema and BP 190/110 mm of Hg. The best drug to manage this patient is?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Prazosin Scorpion Bite Scorpion bite leads to activation of autonomic hyperactivity Excess catecholamines release causes hypertension and prazosin decreases it through its alpha-antagonistic action In case of pulmonary edema and HTN in scorpion stings best drug is prazosin

Highyeild:

𝛂 1 blockers Prazosin Terazosin Doxazosin Alfuzosin Uses: 1) BPH (due to 𝛂 1A blockade) 2) Can be used in other conditions ( due to 𝛂 1B/1D blocking property) like Hypertension Peripheral vascular disease (PVD) like Raynaud’s disease Scorpion sting - DOC - Prazosin Have a beneficial effect on lipid profile

Extraedge:

Scorpion Bite Scorpion bite leads to activation of autonomic hyperactivity Excess catecholamines release causes hypertension and prazosin decreases it through its alpha-antagonistic action In case of pulmonary edema and HTN in scorpion stings best drug is prazosin

Table:

Adrenaline a1, a2, B1 and B2 agonist Can be administered by: -- Subcutaneous --inhalation --eye drops -- intracardiac Actions similar to sympathetic stimulation Cardiovascular system Heart: fall cardiac properties (contractility, heart rate, AV Conduction, excitability, automaticity Blood vessels: Vasoconstriction (skin, mucous membrane, renal) Vasodilatation (skeletal muscle, coronary blood vessels) Blood pressure: ↑systolic blood pressure,↓diastolic blood pressure Noradrenaline • Vasoconstrictor • Increased heart rate and increased inotropy (B1- adrenoceptor mediated) • Vasoconstriction occurs in most systemic arteries and veins (postjunctional a 1 and a 2 adrenoceptors) • Ask can I wake patient up to avoid Norad • Must have a good cardiac output

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy is brought to the Emergency Department. Whilst in school he injected his friend's epinephrine pen into the palm of his left hand. Shortly afterward the left middle finger became cold and pale. The capillary refill time was around 5-6 seconds. What is the most appropriate management?

options.label: A
options.text: Inhalation of Nitrox (mixture of nitrogen + oxygen)

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Local infiltration of phentolamine

Highyeild:

Phentolamine: Phentolamine's ability to block a-adrenergic receptors on blood vessels induces vasodilation In this patient, adrenaline was accidentally injected into the finger and may lead to vasospasm and gangrene So need to infiltrate a vasodilator and it is phentolamine

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A. Nitrox with an oxygen content above 21% , is mainly used in scuba diving to reduce the proportion of nitrogen in the breathing gas mixture. The main benefit is reduced decompression risk. Option B. Nitrates cause a redistribution of blood flow without affecting total coronary flow. Autoregulatory small vessels remain unaffected whereas large conducting vessels are dilated. Nitrates are predominantly venodilators, therefore decreasing mainly preload. Option C. It causes dilation of small blood vessels and can result in flushing and hypotension. Fall in blood pressure is mediated by both H, (early; by release of NO) as well as H₂ (delayed and persistent; direct action on smooth muscles of blood vessels) receptors. It increases capillary permeability and results in edema through stimulation of H, receptors. The intradermal injection may result in a triple response consisting of a red reaction (due to vasodilation), wheal (exudation of fluid due to increased permeability), and flare (spreading redness due to axon reflex). It is primarily a H₁ response.

questions.text: The patient was taken for cataract surgery and developed floppy iris syndrome. On asking he revealed that he is also taking a drug for BPH. What drug patient was taking?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Tamsulosin Tamsulosin Intraoperative floppy iris syndrome is characterized by a triad of flaccid iris stroma that undulates and billows in response to intraocular fluid currents, a propensity for the floppy iris stroma to prolapse toward the phacoemulsification and side-port incisions despite proper wound construction, and progressive intraoperative pupil constriction despite standard preventive preoperative pharmacologic measures It is seen with tamsulosin, so need to take drug history before cataract surgery

questions.text: The following drugs have alpha-blocking property except:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Fluoxetine Drugs having alpha-blocking property TCAs - Amitriptyline Typical antipsychotics - Chlorpromazine Ergots Indoramin used in Raynaud's disease Urapidil used in HTN Labetalol and carvedilol

questions.text: A 45-YEAR-old male patient with erectile dysfunction was given an Intracavernous injection of Phentolamine. All the following adverse effects are possible except:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Impaired ejaculation Direct intracavernous injection of Phentolamine in combination with papaverine has been proposed as a treatment for male sexual dysfunction Intracavernous injection of Phentolamine may cause Orthostatic hypotension Priapism Repetitive intra-penile injections may cause fibrotic reactions Impaired ejaculation is not a known ADR

questions.text: A 70-year-old male had Frequent or urgent need to urinate, Increased frequency of urination at night (nocturia), Difficulty starting urination, Weak urine stream or a stream that stops and starts, and Dribbling at the end of urination and give an alpha-blocker drug. Which is the best drug to prescribe to this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Tamsulosin Tamsulosin is a selective α 1A receptor antagonist and acts mainly on the prostate without affecting alpha receptor subtypes in blood vessels. So the patient will not have hypotension. But other drugs like Prazosin, doxazosin, and tolazoline are non-selective and block alpha 1A and alpha 1B and may cause hypotension in this elderly patient, so better avoid.

questions.text: A 58-year-old male patient had a BMI of 35. His physician started him on a drug for managing obesity. The drug lowers glucose and is given via the Parenteral route. Identify the drug:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Liraglutide Drugs used for obesity management Sympathomimetics Sibutramine(withdrawn) fenfluramine(withdrawn) phentermine Lipase inhibitor Orlistat Cooking medium Olestra Drug combinations Bupropion + naltrexone Bupropion+zonisamide Phentermine + topiramate 5HT2C Agonist Lorcaserin(banned due to increased risk of cancer) GLP 1 agonist Liraglutide

questions.text: Which of the following is the Gq type of receptor?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

alpha 1 Different types of receptors in ANS are alpha 1 Gq alpha 2 Gi Beta 1 Gs Beta 2 Gs D1 Gs D 2 Gi

questions.text: Reflex bradycardia caused by Alpha-1 agonists can be blocked by:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Atropine Atropine is an anticholinergic which causes tachycardia, so this can be used in Reflex bradycardia caused by Alpha-1 agonists Metoprolol is a cardio-selective beta blocker, which causes bradycardia Mirtazapine is an atypical antidepressant and blocks α2 auto receptor Phenylephrine is an alpha agonist, so no action on the heart

questions.text: Midodrine is used in which of the following condition
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Orthostatic hypotension Midodrine is a selective alpha-1 receptor antagonist used in the treatment of orthostatic hypotension It increases upright blood pressure and improves orthostatic tolerance After the oral dose, peak concentration achieved in one hour

questions.text: Which of the following is an irreversible non-selective alpha blocker?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Phenoxybenzamine Phenoxybenzamine is an irreversible non-selective alpha blocker used orally for the treatment of hypertension due to pheochromocytoma Phentolamine is a reversible non-selective alpha blocker Prazosin and Terazosin are selective alpha-1 blockers Irreversible Reversible Phenoxybenzamine Phentolamine Tolazoline Uses : Uses : Pheochromocytoma Cheese Reaction Clonidine withdrawal

options.label: A
options.text: Selective partial agonist at α2β4 subtype of Nicotinic Receptor

options.label: B
options.text: Non-selective full agonist at α4β2 subtype of Nicotinic Receptor

options.label: C
options.text: Selective partial agonist at α4β2 subtype of Nicotinic Receptor

options.label: D
options.text: Selective full agonist at α2β4 subtype of Nicotinic Receptor

questions.correct_answer: C. Selective partial agonist at α4β2 subtype of Nicotinic Receptor
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Selective partial agonist at α4β2 subtype of Nicotinic Receptor Varenicline is a selective partial agonist at the α4β2 subtype of Nicotinic Receptor Marketed as oral tablets for smoking cessation therapy

Extraedge:

Drugs for smoking cessation : Nicotine replacement therapy Long-acting preparations: transdermal patches Shorter acting preparations: gums, lozenges, nasal spray, inhaler mouth spray a Drugs : Varenicline (most effective therapy): it is a nicotinic Alpha4Beta2 partial agonist. Bupropion: it is NDRI ( noradrenaline dopamine reuptake inhibitors ). It is used for smoking cessation along with its anti-depressant properties.

questions.text: The drug used as an antismoking agent is
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Varenicline Varenicline is a partial agonist at α4β2 receptors nicotinic receptor This type of nicotinic receptor subtype is involved in nicotine addiction Used as an antismoking agent FDA has given a warning on CVS risk and increased suicidal risk

Extraedge:

Newer non-FDA approved drugs : Cytisine: Plant alkaloid (action similar to varenicline ) Clonidine (it also has anti-smoking properties) These are the emerging drugs that are not FDA-approved yet.

questions.text: The following statements are true regarding carvedilol except:

options.label: B
options.text: No dose adjustment in renal failure

options.label: D
options.text: α1, β1 blockade and with agonistic activity at β2

questions.correct_answer: D. α1, β1 blockade and with agonistic activity at β2
questions.explanation:
Solution:

α1, β1 blockade and with agonistic activity at β2 Carvedilol - α1, β1 & β2 antagonist Inhibits free radical-induced lipid peroxidation Blocks L-type voltage-gated Calcium channels Decreases vascular smooth muscle mitogenesis Bioavailability is 25% to 35% due to a significant degree of first-pass metabolism No dose adjustment in renal failure as it is metabolized in the liver The metabolites of carvedilol are excreted primarily via the bile into the feces.
